posts.title: 5 Signs Your Electrical Panel Needs an Upgrade
posts.excerpt: An outdated electrical panel can be a safety hazard. Learn when it's time for an upgrade.
posts.content:
Your electrical panel is the heart of your home's electrical system. Here are signs it needs attention:

## 1. Frequent Breaker Trips
If breakers trip regularly, your panel may be overloaded.

## 2. Flickering Lights
Lights dimming when appliances turn on indicates insufficient capacity.

## 3. Burning Smell or Scorch Marks
This is an emergency — call an electrician immediately.

## 4. You Still Have a Fuse Box
Fuse boxes should be upgraded to modern breaker panels for safety.

## 5. Planning Home Additions
New rooms, EV chargers, or hot tubs require additional capacity.

posts.title: The Complete Guide to Home EV Charger Installation
posts.excerpt: Everything you need to know about installing an electric vehicle charger at your Denver home.
posts.content:
Thinking about a home EV charger? Here's what to know:

## Level 1 vs Level 2
- Level 1: Standard outlet, 3-5 miles/hour charge
- Level 2: 240V dedicated circuit, 25-30 miles/hour charge

## What You'll Need
- 240V dedicated circuit (40-60 amps)
- Possible panel upgrade if capacity is limited
- Permit and inspection (we handle this)

## Popular Chargers
- Tesla Wall Connector
- ChargePoint Home Flex
- Emporia Level 2

## Cost Factors
- Distance from panel to garage
- Panel upgrade needed?
- Conduit routing

posts.title: Monsoon Season Electrical Safety Tips for Denver Homes
posts.excerpt: Protect your home and family during Arizona's monsoon season with these electrical safety tips.
posts.content:
Denver's monsoon season brings lightning, wind, and flooding — all threats to your electrical system:

## Before Monsoon Season
- Install whole-home surge protection
- Trim trees near power lines
- Check outdoor outlets have GFCI protection
- Test backup generators

## During Storms
- Unplug sensitive electronics
- Stay away from downed power lines
- Don't use electrical appliances during active lightning

## After Storms
- Check for water intrusion near electrical panels
- Test GFCI outlets
- Look for damage to outdoor wiring
